Enteritis due to Campylobacter
Definition: This refers to inflammation of the small intestine due to infection of bacteria, Campylobacter, a genus of spirally curved motile gram-negative rod-shaped bacteria of which some are pathogenic. This will cause acute enteric disease of variable severity characterised by diarrhoea (frequently with bloody stools), abdominal pain, malaise, fever, nausea and/or vomiting.

Title: Colitis due to Campylobacter
Definition: This refers to inflammation of the large intestine due to infection of bacteria, Campylobacter, a genus of spirally curved motile gram-negative rod-shaped bacteria of which some are pathogenic. This will cause acute enteric disease of variable severity characterised by diarrhoea (frequently with bloody stools), abdominal pain, malaise, fever, nausea and/or vomiting.

Title: Enteritis due to Enterobacter
Definition: This refers to an inflammation of the small intestine, due to an infection with bacteria of the genus Enterobacter, a member of the family Enterobacteriaceae. Bacteria of the genus Enterobacter are common Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic, rod-shaped bacteria.

Title: Abdominal actinomycosis
Definition: This is a cervicofacial infectious bacterial disease caused by Actinomyces species such as Actinomyces israelii or A. gerencseriae. It can also be caused by Propionibacterium propionicus, and the condition is likely to be polymicrobial aerobic anaerobic infection.

Title: Enteritis due to Actinomyces
Definition: This refers to inflammation of the small intestine, caused by an infectious bacterial disease caused by Actinomyces species such as Actinomyces israelii or Actinomyces gerencseriae.

Title: Colitis due to methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus
Definition: This is an inflammation of the large intestine caused by infection with any strain of Staphylococcus aureus that has developed, through the process of evolution, resistance to the vast majority of beta-lactam antibiotics, which include the penicillins (methicillin, dicloxacillin, nafcillin, oxacillin, etc.) and the vast majority of cephalosporins.

Title: Colitis due to Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Definition: This is an inflammation of the large intestine caused by infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Title: Colitis due to Klebsiella oxytoca
Definition: This is an inflammation of the large intestine caused by infection with Klebsiella oxytoca.

Title: Colonic spirochaetosis
Definition: This refers to a condition defined histologically by the presence of spirochetal microorganisms attached to the apical cell membrane of the colorectal epithelium.

Title: Secondary syphilitic proctocolitis
Definition: This refers to a proctocolitis due to syphilis in the second of three stages, that is venereal disease caused by Treponema pallidum.

Title: Brachyspira colitis
Definition: This is a disease in the colon caused by the bacterium Brachyspira pilosicoli, that is a member of the Spirochaeta family.

Title: Enteritis due to Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Definition: This refers to an inflammation of the small intestine due to an infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is most commonly caused by the ingestion of substances contaminated with pathogenic microorganisms.

Title: Bacterial foodborne intoxications
Definition: Any condition caused by an intoxication due to a bacterial toxin. Intoxication is by ingestion of contaminated food.

Title: Botulism
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the gram-positive bacteria Clostridium botulinum. This disease commonly presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, acute paralysis, blurred vision, diplopia, and may be fatal. Transmission is by ingestion of contaminated food, direct contact, or from accidental overdose. Confirmation is by identification of Clostridium botulinum in a faecal or food sample.

Title: Inhalational botulism
Definition: Inhalational botulism is a man-made form of botulism, a rare acquired neuromuscular junction disease with descending flaccid paralysis caused by botulinum neurotoxins (BoNTs). The disease results from accidental or intentional release of aerosolized BoNTs.

Title: Iatrogenic botulism
Definition: Iatrogenic botulism is the most recent man-made form of botulism, a rare acquired neuromuscular junction disease with descending flaccid paralysis caused by botulinum neurotoxins (BoNTs), and it may occur as an adverse event after therapeutic or cosmetic use.

Title: Wound botulism
Definition: Wound botulism is a rare infectious form of botulism, a rare acquired neuromuscular junction disease with descending flaccid paralysis due to botulinum neurotoxins (BoNTs), produced after infection of wounds by Clostridium botulinum.

Title: Adult intestinal botulism
Definition: Adult intestinal botulism is a very rare form of botulism, a rare acquired neuromuscular junction disease with descending flaccid paralysis caused by botulinum neurotoxins (BoNTs), and is due to intestinal colonization by Clostridium botulinum leading to toxin-mediated infection with toxaemia.

Title: Infant intestinal botulism
Definition: Infant botulism is a rare form of botulism, a rare acquired neuromuscular junction disease with descending flaccid paralysis caused by botulinum neurotoxins (BoNTs). It is due to intestinal colonization by Clostridium botulinum leading to toxin-mediated infection with toxaemia.

Title: Toxin-mediated infectious botulism
Definition: Infectious botulism is a form of botulism, a rare acquired paralysing neuromuscular junction disease, characterised by descending flaccid paralysis caused by botulinum neurotoxins (BoNTs) produced in vivo leading to toxin-mediated infection. Infectious botulism includes wound botulism and intestinal toxaemia botulism (infant botulism and adult intestinal botulism).

Title: Disorders of the neuromuscular junction in botulism
Definition: Disorders of neuromuscular junction in botulism are rare diseases caused by exposure to the neurotoxins produced by the anaerobe Clostridium botulinum. The three toxin subtypes A, B and E all act by cleaving a coordinated assembly of proteins, such as syntaxin 1, SNAP 25 and synaptobrevin, that bring the vesicle and the plasma membranes into close apposition, in preparation for exocytosis. Their action prevents the close apposition of vesicles to the presynaptic membrane, leading to a failure of acetylcholine release.

Title: Foodborne Clostridium difficile intoxication
Definition: This refers to an intestinal disorder caused by eating foods contaminated with toxins produced by Clostridium difficile.

Title: Foodborne Vibrio parahaemolyticus intoxication
Definition: Foodborne Vibrio parahaemolyticus intoxication is gastroenteritis caused by attaching V. parahaemolyticus to an individuals' small intestine and excreting an as yet unidentified toxin. The incubation period is a mean of 15 hours after the ingestion of the organism. The symptoms with usually mild or moderate include diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, headache, fever, and chills.

Title: Viral intestinal infections
Definition: Any condition of the intestines, caused by an infection with a viral source.

Title: Enteritis due to Adenovirus
Definition: A disease of the intestinal tract, caused by an infection with adenovirus. This disease is characterised by a fever, diarrhoea, or vomiting. Transmission is by the faecal-oral route.

Title: Gastroenteritis due to Rotavirus
Definition: A disease of the gastrointestinal tract, caused by an infection with rotavirus. This disease is characterised by acute onset of vomiting, non-haemorrhagic diarrhoea, and abdominal pain. Transmission is by ingestion of contaminated food or water, direct contact, or through fomites. Confirmation is by identification of rotavirus.

Title: Enteritis due to Norovirus
Definition: A disease of the gastrointestinal tract, caused by an infection with norovirus. This disease is characterised by acute onset of vomiting, non-haemorrhagic diarrhoea, and abdominal pain. Transmission is by ingestion of contaminated food or water, direct contact, or through fomites. Confirmation is by identification of norovirus.

Title: Herpes simplex virus duodenitis
Definition: Duodenitis due to Herpes simplex virus, especially occurred in immunocompromised host.

Title: Intestinal infections due to Cytomegalovirus
Definition: A condition of the intestinal tract, caused by an infection with cytomegalovirus. The condition is characterised by diarrhoea, fever, abdominal pain, or haematochezia. Transmission is by direct contact with infected body fluids.

Title: Duodenitis due to Cytomegalovirus
Definition: This is an inflammation of the lining of the duodenum caused by infection with a viral genus of the viral family Herpesviridae, cytomegalovirus.

Title: Gastritis due to Cytomegalovirus
Definition: This is an inflammation of the lining of the stomach caused by infection with a viral genus of the viral family Herpesviridae, cytomegalovirus.

Title: Enteritis due to Cytomegalovirus
Definition: This is an inflammation of the lining of the small intestine caused by infection with a viral genus of the viral family Herpesviridae, cytomegalovirus.

Title: Colitis due to Cytomegalovirus
Definition: This is an inflammation of the lining of the large intestine caused by infection with a viral genus of the viral family Herpesviridae, cytomegalovirus.

Title: Human immunodeficiency virus disease enteritis
Definition: This is an inflammation of small intestine associated with infection with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). In diarrhoea, a major complication of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) disease, the etiology of which is often obscure.

Title: Enteroviral gastritis
Definition: This is an inflammation of the lining of the stomach from a genus of positive-sense single-stranded RNA viruses, enteroviruses.

Title: Viral colitis
Definition: Viral colitis is inflammation of the large intestine due to infection by viruses. This includes infection with cytomegalovirus, herpes simplex virus, human papilloma virus and other viral infections in the large intestine.

Title: Enteritis due to Calicivirus
Definition: A viral infectious disease of the small bowel that results in secretory diarrhoea.

Title: Oesophageal candidosis
Definition: Oesophageal candidiasis is an opportunistic infection of the oesophagus by Candida albicans. The disease usually occurs in patients in immunocompromised states.

Title: Gastric candidosis
Definition: Gastric candidiasis is an opportunistic infection of the stomach by Candida albicans. The disease usually occurs in patients in immunocompromised states.

Title: Candida enteritis
Definition: This is an inflammation of small intestine caused by infection with Candida albicans. Enteric candidiasis is an opportunistic infection and the disease usually occurs in patients in immunocompromised states.

Title: Duodenal candidosis
Definition: Duodenal candidiasis is an opportunistic infection of the duodenum by Candida albicans. The disease usually occurs in patients in immunocompromised states.

Title: Candida colitis
Definition: This is an inflammation of the colon caused by infection with Candida albicans. Colonic candidiasis is an opportunistic infection and the disease usually occurs in patients in immunocompromised states.

Title: Invasive aspergillosis of the digestive tract
Enterocolitis due to aspergillosis
Definition: This is an inflammation of the intestines caused by infection with fungi of the genus Aspergillus.

Title: Oesophageal aspergillosis
Definition: Oesophageal inflammation caused by infection by fungi of the genus Aspergillus.

Title: Protozoal intestinal infections
Definition: Any condition of the intestines, caused by an infection with a protozoal parasitic source.

Title: Infections due to Balantidium coli
Definition: Any condition caused by an infection with the protozoan parasite Balantidium coli.

Title: Dysentery due to Balantidium coli
Definition: This is an inflammatory disorder of the intestine, especially of the colon, that results in severe diarrhoea containing mucus and/or blood in the faeces with fever, abdominal pain, and rectal tenesmus (a feeling of incomplete defecation), caused by any kind of infection. This diagnosis is due to a parasitic species of ciliate protozoan that causes the disease Balantidiasis.

Title: Colitis due to Balantidium coli
Definition: This is an inflammation of large intestine caused by infection with the largest protozoan, Balantidium coli.

Title: Giardiasis
Definition: A condition caused by an infection with the protozoan parasite Giardia. This condition is characterised by gastroenteritis, or may be asymptomatic. Transmission is by the faecal-oral route from the ingestion of contaminated food or water. Confirmation is by identification of Giardia in a faecal sample.

Title: Duodenitis due to Giardia lamblia
Definition: Giardiasis of duodenum, or duodenitis due to Giardia lamblia is an duodenal inflammation caused by the parasite Giardia lamblia, that is also known as Giardia intestinalis.

Title: Enteritis due to Giardia lamblia
Definition: This refers to an infection of the small intestine with a flagellated protozoan parasite, giardia lamblia that colonizes and reproduces in the small intestine, causing giardiasis. This protozoan parasite grows in the upper portions of the small intestine and produces greasy, smelly diarrhoea.

Title: Colitis due to Giardia lamblia
Definition: This refers to an infection of the large intestine with a flagellated protozoan parasite, giardia lamblia.

Title: Cryptosporidiosis
Definition: Any condition caused by an infection with the protozoan parasite Cryptosporidium.

Title: Cryptosporidial gastritis
Definition: Gastric inflammation caused by infection by a coccidian protozoan parasite, Cryptosporidium.

Title: Cryptosporidial enteritis
Definition: This refers to an infection of the small intestine with a genus of protozoans, Cryptosporidium that causes diarrhoea in humans. Cryptosporidium is the organism most commonly isolated in HIV-positive patients presenting with diarrhoea.

Title: Cryptosporidial colitis
Definition: This refers to an infection of the large intestine with a genus of protozoans, Cryptosporidium that causes diarrhoea in humans.

Title: Cystoisosporiasis
Definition: A disease caused by the protozoan parasite Cystoisospora belli. This disease is characterised by watery diarrhoea, fever, abdominal pain, nausea, or malaise. Transmission is by the faecal-oral route, commonly through the ingestion of contaminated food or water. Confirmation is by identification of Cystoisospora belli in a faecal sample.

Title: Cystoisosporiasis of colon
Definition: Isosporiasis of colon is a large intestinal inflammation caused by the protozoan Isospora belli.

Title: Cyclosporiasis
Definition:
Cyclosporosis is a parasitic disease caused by Cyclospora cayetanensis that occurs through ingestion of contaminated food or water and leads to abdominal pain, anorexia and diarrhoea, which may resolve spontaneously in immunocompetent individuals but may persist in a chronic form in immunocompromised subjects, leading to a decline in their general state of health.
An emerging gastro-enteric disease caused by the coccidia protozoan Cyclospora cayetanensis, a pathogen transmitted by faeces or faeces-contaminated fresh produce and water. It is associated with diarrhoea among children in developing countries.

Title: Intestinal trichomoniasis
Definition: This refers to intestinal infection by the flagellate protozoan parasite Trichomonas.

Title: Sarcocystosis
Definition: Any condition caused by an infection with the protozoan parasite Sarcocystis.

Title: Acute amoebiasis
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica. This disease is characterised by fever, abdominal pain, tenesmus, or diarrhoea containing blood. Transmission is by the faecal-oral route or ingestion of contaminated food or water. Confirmation is by identification of Entamoeba histolytica in a faecal or blood sample.

Title: Enteritis due to Entamoeba
Definition: This is an inflammation of small intestine caused by infection with the protozoan Entamoeba histolytica.

Title: Chronic amoebiasis
Definition: A symptomatic form of amoebiasis (E. histolytica infection) characterised by long-standing infection and severe diarrhoea.

Title: Chronic amoebiasis
Definition: A symptomatic form of amoebiasis (E. histolytica infection) characterised by long-standing infection and severe diarrhoea.

Title: Amoeboma of large intestine
Definition: This is a rare complication of entamoeba histolytica, where in response to the infecting amoeba there is formation of annular colonic granulation, which results in a large local lesion of the bowel, in the large intestine.

Title: Acute amoebiasis
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica. This disease is characterised by fever, abdominal pain, tenesmus, or diarrhoea containing blood. Transmission is by the faecal-oral route or ingestion of contaminated food or water. Confirmation is by identification of Entamoeba histolytica in a faecal or blood sample.

Title: Enteritis due to Entamoeba
Definition: This is an inflammation of small intestine caused by infection with the protozoan Entamoeba histolytica.

Title: Chronic amoebiasis
Definition: A symptomatic form of amoebiasis (E. histolytica infection) characterised by long-standing infection and severe diarrhoea.

Title: Amoeboma of large intestine
Definition: This is a rare complication of entamoeba histolytica, where in response to the infecting amoeba there is formation of annular colonic granulation, which results in a large local lesion of the bowel, in the large intestine.

Title: Amoebic abscess of lung and liver
Amoebic brain abscess
Definition: Amoebic abscesses resulting from hematogenous spread have occasionally been described in the brain Cerebral amebiasis has an abrupt onset and rapid progression to death in 12-72 hours. The patient presents with altered consciousness and focal neurologic signs. CT scanning reveals irregular lesions without a surrounding capsule or enhancement. A tissue biopsy sample reveals the trophozoites.

Title: Amoebic abscess of brain and liver
Amoebic abscess of brain, liver, and lung
Amoebiasis of penis
Definition: Penile amoebiasis can present as a purulent balanoposthitis or as an ulcer of the prepuce or glans, when it may simulate a squamous carcinoma. It generally follows penetrative anal intercourse with an individual with intestinal amoebiasis.

Title: Gastroenteritis or colitis without specification of infectious agent
Gastroenteritis or colitis without specification of origin
Definition: There is no mention whether the gastroenteritis or colitis is infectious or non-infectious.

Title: Syphilis
Definition: A predominantly sexually transmitted infection caused by Treponema pallidum ssp. pallidum.

Title: Congenital syphilis
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Treponema pallidum pallidum in utero. This disease may present with clinical signs depending on the stage of disease. Transmission is by vertical transmission.

Title: Early congenital syphilis
Definition: A disease affecting newborns or children up to 2 years of age, caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Treponema pallidum pallidum in utero. Transmission is by vertical transmission. Confirmation is by prenatal screening.

Title: Early congenital syphilis, symptomatic
Definition: A disease affecting newborns or children up to 2 years of age, caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Treponema pallidum pallidum in utero. This disease is characterised by premature birth, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal abnormalities, and bullous skin disease. Transmission is by vertical transmission.

Title: Late congenital syphilis
Definition: Congenital syphilis presenting after two years of age and often not until many years later. Saddle nose and peg-shaped (Hutchinson's) teeth are pathognomonic. As in late acquired syphilis, gummata, periostitis, optic atrophy, deafness, paralysis and dementia may develop when treatment is delayed.

Title: Late congenital syphilitic oculopathy
Definition: This is a late congenital, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with oculopathy.

Title: Late congenital syphilitic interstitial keratitis
Definition: This is a late congenital, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with interstitial keratitis.

Title: Late congenital syphilitic optic atrophy
Definition: This is a late congenital, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with optic atrophy.

Title: Late congenital neurosyphilis
Definition: Neurological sequelae of longstanding (> 2 years) untreated congenital neurosyphilis include mental delay, hydrocephalus, seizures, cerebral infarction and cranial nerve palsies.

Title: Juvenile syphilis of central nervous system with general paralysis
Juvenile syphilis of central nervous system with taboparesis
Late congenital syphilitic encephalitis
Definition: This is a late congenital, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with encephalitis.

Title: Late congenital syphilitic polyneuropathy
Definition: This is a late congenital, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with polyneuropathy.

Title: Late congenital syphilitic sensorineural deafness
Definition: This is a late congenital, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with sensorineural deafness.

Title: Late congenital syphilitic osteochondropathy
Definition: This is a late congenital, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with osteochondropathy.

Title: Late congenital syphilitic arthropathy
Definition: This is a late congenital, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with syphilitic arthropathy.

Title: Early syphilis
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Treponema pallidum pallidum, including primary and secondary stages of syphilis, and early latent syphilis of less than 2 years duration. This disease is characterised by a single chancre in the primary stage, and diffuse rash in the secondary stage. Transmission is commonly by sexual contact.

Title: Primary genital syphilis
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Treponema pallidum pallidum. This disease is characterised by a single chancre in the genital region. Transmission is commonly by sexual contact.

Title: Secondary syphilis of skin or mucous membranes
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with Treponema pallidum pallidum. This disease is characterised by lesions of the skin and mucous membranes. Transmission is commonly by sexual contact.

Title: Macular syphilide
Definition: The earliest manifestation of secondary syphilis which appears on average eight weeks after initial infection as widespread, symmetrical, copper-red, round and oval macules which, on the back, follow the lines of skin cleavage. It is asymptomatic and can be easily overlooked.

Title: Condylomata lata
Definition: This is a cutaneous condition characterised by wart like lesions on the genitals. They are generally symptoms of the secondary phase of syphilis, caused by the spirochete, Treponema pallidum.

Title: Cutaneous complications of secondary syphilis
Definition: Less common cutaneous manifestations of secondary syphilis

Title: Lues maligna
Definition: A fulminant nodulo-ulcerative form of secondary syphilis which is more prevalent in individuals with HIV infection.

Title: Syphilitic leukoderma
Definition: An uncommon presentation of secondary syphilis which may be mistaken for vitiligo.

Title: Syphilitic alopecia
Definition: Secondary syphilis may result in a moth-eaten alopecia of the scalp, resembling a rather diffuse and patchy alopecia areata; other body areas, especially the eyebrows and beard, may be affected. Less commonly, diffuse hair loss occurs in the absence of other cutaneous signs of syphilis and resembling the diffuse hair loss of telogen effluvium (essential syphilitic alopecia). Syphilitic alopecia is non-scarring except in the rare nodulo-ulcerative form of secondary syphilis known as lues maligna: this is a necrotizing vasculitis which can result in permanent hair follicle destruction in the scalp and other areas of the body.

Title: Secondary syphilis of other sites
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Treponema pallidum pallidum. This disease is characterised by less common symptoms of syphilis, including hepatitis, kidney disease, arthritis, periostitis, optic neuritis, uveitis, or interstitial keratitis. Transmission is commonly by sexual contact.

Title: Early syphilis involving the eye
Definition: Ocular secondary syphilis may manifest as acute iritis, posterior uveitis, panuveitis, diffuse chorioretinitis or perivasculitis.

Title: Secondary syphilitic anterior uveitis
Definition: This refers to a secondary, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with anterior uveitis.

Title: Early syphilis involving the digestive tract
Definition: This is an early sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is involving the digestive tract.

Title: Secondary syphilitic proctocolitis
Definition: This refers to a proctocolitis due to syphilis in the second of three stages, that is venereal disease caused by Treponema pallidum.

Title: Secondary syphilitic hepatitis
Definition: Clinical hepatitis is rare in the secondary spirochaetal septicaemic stage. However, sometimes the picture is of severe cholestatic jaundice.

Title: Secondary syphilitic gastritis
Definition: Symptomatic secondary syphilitic gastritis is uncommon, occurring in less than 1% of patients with syphilis in the antibiotic era. The most common symptoms include nausea, vomiting, epigastric pain and anorexia; rarely, acute bleeding, gastric perforation and/or obstruction may occur.

Title: Early syphilis involving the musculoskeletal system
Definition: This is an early sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is involving the musculoskeletal system.

Title: Secondary syphilitic synovitis or tenosynovitis
Definition: This is a disorder of inflammation of the joint lining or tendon sheath which causes progressive amounts of pain and is secondary to a syphilitic infection.

Title: Secondary syphilitic periostitis
Definition: This refers to a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum, causing inflammation of the periosteum.

Title: Symptomatic early neurosyphilis
Definition: A rare manifestation of syphilis which usually occurs within the first twelve months of infection. The clinical forms of the condition include acute or subacute meningitis, cranial nerve dysfunction and inflammatory cerebral vasculitis presenting as stroke. The risk is greatly increased by co-infection with HIV.

Title: Secondary syphilitic female pelvic inflammatory disease
Latent early syphilis
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Treponema pallidum pallidum. This disease is characterised by serologic proof of infection without symptoms of disease less than 1 year after secondary syphilis. Transmission is commonly by sexual contact.

Title: Late syphilis
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Treponema pallidum pallidum. This disease is characterised by gummas, neurological abnormalities, or cardiac abnormalities. Clinical signs normally manifest approximately 3-15 years after initial infection. Transmission is commonly by sexual contact.

Title: Neurosyphilis
Definition: A disease of the brain or spinal cord caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Treponema pallidum pallidum. This disease is characterised by four different forms: meningovascular, tabes dorsalis, general paresis, or may be asymptomatic. Clinical signs normally manifest approximately 4-25 years after initial infection. Transmission is commonly by sexual contact.

Title: Symptomatic late neurosyphilis
Definition: A diverse constellation of neuropsychiatric signs resulting from prolonged untreated or inadequately treated syphilis. The protean clinical manifestations include chronic, insidious meningeal inflammation with cranial nerve palsy, cognitive and/or behavioural impairment, ataxia, stroke, seizures and visual or auditory impairment.

Title: Meningovascular syphilis
Definition: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is involving the meningovascular.

Title: Late syphilitic encephalitis
Definition: This is a late, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is involving acute inflammation of the brain.

Title: Syphilitic parkinsonism
Definition: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with a neurological syndrome characterised by tremor, hypokinesia, rigidity, and postural instability.

Title: Late syphilitic polyneuropathy
Definition: This is a late, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis with a serious, unpredictable, occasionally progressive, and life threatening neurological disorder that occurs when many nerves throughout the body malfunction simultaneously.

Title: Tabes dorsalis
Definition: This is a slow degeneration (specifically, demyelination) of the sensory neurons that carry afferent information. The degenerating nerves are in the dorsal columns (posterior columns) of the spinal cord (the portion closest to the back of the body) and carry information that help maintain a person's sense of position (proprioception), vibration, and discriminative touch.

Title: Myelitis due to Treponema pallidum
Definition: An inflammatory disorder of the spinal cord due to infection by Treponema pallidum. The symptoms and signs may be acute or subacute in onset, and include paraparesis or paraplegia, sensory loss appropriate with the level of the spinal cord affected, loss of sphincter control, and lower motor neurone signs. The spinal fluid usually shows a lymphocytosis, elevated protein level, and a normal or slightly low glucose level. Diagnosis may be confirmed by neuroimaging, spinal fluid analysis, and serological tests for syphilis.

Title: Dementia due to neurosyphilis
Definition: Dementia due to neurosyphilis, a disease of the central nervous system caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Treponema pallidum, with brain involvement, and supportive clinical, imaging and laboratory features of the disease without another identifiable cause of cognitive dysfunction. There may be associated psychiatric symptoms. This type of dementia is considered to be treatable and, therefore, reversible (at least partially).

Title: Meningitis due to Treponema pallidum
Definition: This is an infectious disease caused by the inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord known as the meninges. It develops in response to a bacterial infection of the cerebrospinal fluid by Treponema pallidum.

Title: Cardiovascular late syphilis
Definition: This is a late, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is involving the cardiovascular area.

Title: Syphilitic aortic incompetence
Definition: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is involving aortic incompetence.

Title: Syphilitic pulmonary regurgitation
Definition: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is involving pulmonary regurgitation.

Title: Syphilitic endocarditis
Definition: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum, causing inflammation of the inner layer of the heart, the endocardium.

Title: Syphilitic myocarditis
Definition: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum, causing inflammation of heart muscle (myocardium).

Title: Syphilitic aortitis
Definition: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum, causing inflammation of the aortic wall.

Title: Syphilitic aneurysm of aorta
Definition: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum, causing an aneurysm of the aorta.

Title: Syphilitic cerebral arteritis
Definition: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with cerebral arteritis.

Title: Symptomatic late syphilis of other sites
Ocular late syphilis
Definition: This is a late, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with ocular.

Title: Late syphilitic episcleritis
Definition: This is a late, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with a benign, self-limiting inflammatory disease affecting part of the eye called the episclera.

Title: Late syphilitic posterior uveitis
Definition: This is a late, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with posterior uveitis.

Title: Late syphilitic retrobulbar neuritis
Definition: This is a late, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with retrobulbar neuritis.

Title: Late syphilitic optic atrophy
Definition: This is a late, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is with an optic atrophy.

Title: Late syphilis involving the musculoskeletal system
Definition: This is a late, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is involving the musculoskeletal system.

Title: Syphilitic Charcot arthropathy
Definition: A form of neuropathic arthropathy which arises as a complication of late syphilitic polyneuropathy. Joint destruction, most commonly involving the lower extremities, results from damage to sensory nerves.

Title: Syphilitic osteopathy or osteochondropathy
Definition: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is involving osteopathy or osteochondropathy.

Title: Late syphilitic bursitis
Definition: This is a long-standing disorder of inflammation of one or more bursae (small sacs) of synovial fluid in the body which usually results in pain and is caused by a syphilitic agent.

Title: Late syphilitic bursitis, pelvic region or thigh
Late syphilitic bursitis, ankle or foot
Late syphilitic bursitis, other joints in foot
Late syphilis of skin or mucous membranes
Definition: This is a late, sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is involving the skin and mucous membranes.

Title: Pulmonary late syphilis
Definition: This is a pulmonary, late sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum.

Title: Renal late syphilis
Definition: Renal involvement in late syphilis is uncommon but may manifest as membranous glomerulonephritis, mesangial and endothelial cell proliferative glomerulonephritis, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and nephrotic syndrome.

Title: Late syphilitic female pelvic inflammatory disease
Definition: This is a late sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum. This diagnosis is involving inflammation of the uterus, fallopian tubes, and/or ovaries as it progresses to scar formation with adhesions to nearby tissues and organs.

Title: Secondary syphilitic hepatitis
Definition: Clinical hepatitis is rare in the secondary spirochaetal septicaemic stage. However, sometimes the picture is of severe cholestatic jaundice.

Title: Syphilitic peritonitis
Definition: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pallidum, that causes an inflammation of the peritoneum, the thin tissue that lines the inner wall of the abdomen and covers most of the abdominal organs.

Title: Latent late syphilis
Definition: Syphilis (acquired) without clinical manifestations, with positive serological reaction and negative spinal fluid test, two years or more after infection.

Title: Latent syphilis, unspecified as early or late
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Treponema pallidum pallidum. This disease is characterised by serologic proof of infection without symptoms of disease. Transmission is commonly by sexual contact.

Title: Syphilis complicating pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium
Definition: Syphilis complicating pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium

Title: Interstitial keratitis and keratoconjunctivitis in syphilis
Female syphilitic pelvic inflammatory disease
Definition: Inflammation of the uterus, fallopian tubes, or ovaries due to infection with Treponema pallidum (Syphilis), which may progress to scar formation with adhesions to nearby tissues and organs.

Title: Gonococcal infection
Definition: A condition caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Transmission is by sexual contact. Confirmation is by identification of Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Title: Gonococcal infection of lower genitourinary tract without periurethral or accessory gland abscess
Acute gonococcal infection of lower genitourinary tract
Chronic gonococcal infection of lower genitourinary tract
Gonococcal infection of lower genitourinary tract with periurethral or accessory gland abscess
Gonococcal epididymitis
Definition: This is a condition characterised by discomfort or pain in of the epididymis, a curved structure at the back of the testicle in which sperm matures and is stored.

Title: Gonococcal orchitis
Definition: This is inflammation of the testes. It can also involve swelling, heavy pains and frequent infection, and is more rarely known as didymitis (as in epididymis).

Title: Gonococcal pelviperitonitis
Definition: This is an inflammation of the peritoneum, the thin tissue that lines the inner wall of the abdomen and covers most of the abdominal organs.

Title: Acute gonococcal infection of upper genitourinary tract, site unspecified
Female gonococcal pelvic inflammatory disease
Definition: A disease of the reproductive system in females, caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This disease is characterised by fever, lower abdomen pain, vaginal discharge, pain during intercourse, burning sensation during urination, or bleeding between periods. Transmission is by sexual contact (an ascending infection in the vagina commonly due to sexual intercourse).

Title: Gonococcal peritonitis
Definition: This is an inflammation of the peritoneum, the thin tissue that lines the inner wall of the abdomen and covers most of the abdominal organs, caused by gonococcal infection.

Title: Gonococcal infection of musculoskeletal system
Definition: This is a species of Gram-negative coffee bean-shaped diplococci bacteria responsible for the sexually transmitted infection gonorrhoea. This diagnosis is of the musculoskeletal system.

Title: Gonococcal bursitis
Definition: This is a disorder of inflammation of one or more bursae (small sacs) of synovial fluid in the body which usually results in pain and is caused by a gonococcal agent.

Title: Gonococcal bursitis, pelvic region or thigh
Gonococcal bursitis, other joints in foot
Gonococcal osteomyelitis
Definition: This means an infection of the bone or bone marrow. It can be usefully subclassified on the basis of the causative organism (pyogenic bacteria or mycobacteria), the route, duration and anatomic location of the infection.

Title: Gonococcal synovitis
Definition: This is a disorder of inflammation of the synovial membrane or joint lining which causes progressive amounts of pain and is the result of a gonococcal infection.

Title: Gonococcal tenosynovitis
Definition: This is inflammation of the fluid-filled sheath (called the synovium) that surrounds a tendon which can cause progressive amounts of pain and is the result of a gonococcal infection.

Title: Gonococcal infection of rectum
Definition: This is a species of Gram-negative coffee bean-shaped diplococci bacteria responsible for the sexually transmitted infection gonorrhoea of the rectum.

Title: Gonococcal infection of anus
Definition: This is a species of Gram-negative coffee bean-shaped diplococci bacteria responsible for the sexually transmitted infection gonorrhoea. This diagnosis is of the anus.

Title: Gonococcal infection of eye
Definition: This is a species of Gram-negative coffee bean-shaped diplococci bacteria responsible for the sexually transmitted infection gonorrhoea. This diagnosis is of the eye.

Title: Gonococcal anterior uveitis
Definition: This is broadly defined as inflammation of the uvea. The uvea consists of the middle, pigmented, vascular structures of the eye and includes the iris, ciliary body, and choroid.

Title: Neonatal conjunctivitis or dacryocystitis due to Neisseria gonorrhoeae
Definition: This is a form of conjunctivitis contracted by newborns during delivery. The baby's eyes are contaminated during passage through the birth canal from a mother infected with either Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This diagnosis is due to a species of Gram-negative coffee bean-shaped diplococci bacteria responsible for the sexually transmitted infection gonorrhoea.

Title: Gonococcal brain abscess
Definition: This is a gonococcal abscess caused by inflammation and collection of infected material, coming from local (ear infection, dental abscess, infection of paranasal sinuses, infection of the mastoid air cells of the temporal bone, epidural abscess) or remote (lung, heart, kidney etc.) infectious sources, within the brain tissue.

Title: Gonococcal endocarditis
Definition: This is a gonococcal inflammation of the inner layer of the heart, the endocardium. It usually involves the heart valves (native or prosthetic valves).

Title: Gonococcal myocarditis
Definition: Bacterial myocarditis (bacterial inflammatory cardiomyopathy) due to Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Title: Gonococcal pericarditis
Definition: This is a gonococcal inflammation of the pericardium (the fibrous sac surrounding the heart). A characteristic chest pain is often present.

Title: Neisseria gonorrhoeae dacryoadenitis
Definition: This is a species of Gram-negative coffee bean-shaped diplococci bacteria responsible for the sexually transmitted infection gonorrhoea. This diagnosis is with inflammation of the lacrimal glands (the tear-producing glands).

Title: Disseminated gonococcal infection
Definition: Disseminated gonococcal infection occurs when there is bacteremic dissemination of Neisseria gonorrhoeae from its initial focus of infection mainly in female pelvic organs. It manifests as pain and swelling around one or more joints, intermittent crops of erythematous papules and pustules on the limbs, fever and rigors. Blood cultures may be but are not always positive.

Title: Gonorrhoea complicating pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium
Sexually transmissible infections due to chlamydia
Definition: An infection with the gram-negative intracellular bacteria Chlamydia trachomatis. This infection may be asymptomatic or characterised by fever, painful urination, urinary urgency, dyspareunia, vaginal bleeding or discharge, pain in the abdomen in females and by fever, urethritis, painful urination, discharge from the penis, swollen or tender testicles in males. Transmission is by anal, vaginal, or oral sex. Confirmation is by identification of Chlamydia trachomatis.

Title: Chlamydial lymphogranuloma
Definition: A disease of the inguinal lymph glands, caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Chlamydia trachomatis. This disease is characterised by a genital ulcer, buboes, abscesses in the groin, blood in faeces, tenesmus, or proctocolitis. Transmission is by sexual contact. Confirmation is by identification of Chlamydia trachomatis in a blood sample or by polymerase chain reaction tests.

Title: Sexually transmitted diseases due to Chlamydia trachomatis
Chlamydial infection of lower genitourinary tract
Chlamydial cystitis or urethritis
Definition: This is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) in humans caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. This diagnosis is with cystitis and urethritis.

Title: Chlamydial vulvovaginitis
Definition: This is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) in humans caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. This diagnosis is with an inflammation of the vagina.

Title: Chlamydial cervicitis
Definition: This is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) in humans caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. This diagnosis is with an inflammation of the uterine cervix.

Title: Chlamydial infection of internal reproductive organs
Chlamydial female pelvic inflammatory disease
Definition: This is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) in humans caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. This diagnosis is of the internal reproductive organs.

Title: Chlamydial infection of male internal reproductive organs
Definition: This is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) in humans caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. This diagnosis is of the male internal reproductive organs.

Title: Chlamydial epididymitis
Definition: This is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) in humans caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. This diagnosis is with a condition characterised by discomfort or pain in of the epididymis, a curved structure at the back of the testicle in which sperm matures and is stored.

Title: Chlamydial orchitis
Definition: This is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) in humans caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. This diagnosis is with inflammation of the testes.

Title: Chlamydial infection of anus or rectum
Definition: This is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) in humans caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. This diagnosis is with infection of anus and rectum.

Title: Chlamydial infection of rectum
Definition: This is an inflammation of rectum caused by infection with Chlamydia Trachomatis.

Title: Chlamydial colitis
Definition: This is an inflammation of the large intestine caused by infection with Chlamydia Trachomatis.

Title: Chancroid
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the gram-negative bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi. This disease is characterised by painful ulcer(s) on the genitalia. Transmission is by sexual contact. Confirmation is by identification of Haemophilus ducreyi from the ulcer exudate.

Title: Colonic infection due to Haemophilus ducreyi
Definition: This is an infection in the colon due to a fastidious gram-negative coccobacillus, Haemophilus ducreyi, causing the sexually transmitted disease chancroid, a major cause of genital ulceration in developing countries characterised by painful sores on the genitalia.

Title: Granuloma inguinale
Definition: A disease caused by infection with the gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis. It commonly presents with painless genital ulceration following contact with an infected sexual partner. Small, painless nodules appear after an incubation period of about 1040 days; later the nodules break down to create open, fleshy, oozing ulcers which gradually extend, mutilating the infected tissue. The lesions occur at the region of contact and are typically found on the shaft of the penis, the labia, or the perineum.

Title: Genital granuloma inguinale
Definition: The common form of granuloma inguinale, which is confined to the genital area.

Title: Extragenital granuloma inguinale
Definition: Klebsiella granulomatis, the causative organism of granuloma inguinale, may rarely cause localised or disseminated infection of extragenital sites including lymph nodes and bone.

Title: Osteomyelitis due to Klebsiella granuloma inguinale
Trichomoniasis
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the protozoan parasite Trichomonas. This disease presents with symptoms depending on the site of infection.

Title: Intestinal trichomoniasis
Definition: This refers to intestinal infection by the flagellate protozoan parasite Trichomonas.

Title: Urogenital trichomoniasis
Definition: A disease of the urogenital tract, caused by an infection with the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. In females, this disease is characterised by itching, burning, redness of the genitals, discomfort with urination, or a thin discharge that is clear, yellowish, or greenish; in males, this disease is characterised by itching or irritation inside the penis, burning after urination or ejaculation, or discharge from the penis. Transmission is by sexual contact. Confirmation is by identification of Trichomonas vaginalis in a vaginal or urethral fluid sample.

Title: Prostatitis due to Trichomonas vaginalis
Definition: This refers to an inflammation of the prostate gland caused by an infection with the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis.

Title: Sexually transmissible infections due to Herpes simplex virus
Definition: A condition caused by an infection with Herpes simplex virus (human herpesviruses 1 and 2). This condition is characterised by different clinical symptoms according to the virus. This condition may present with a blister or multiple blisters on or around affected areas (commonly the mouth, genitals, or rectum). Transmission is by sexual contact. Confirmation is by identification of Herpes simplex virus.

Title: Anogenital herpes simplex infection
Definition: A condition of the anogenital region, caused by an infection with herpes simplex virus type 1 or 2. This condition is characterised by vesicles, or may be asymptomatic. Transmission is by sexual contact. Confirmation is by identification of herpes simplex virus type 1 or 2.

Title: Herpes simplex infection of genitalia or urogenital tract
Definition: Herpes simplex infection affecting the vulva and vagina in women and the penis in men. It is more commonly due to infection with Herpes simplex type 2 virus than with type 1 virus.

Title: Primary herpetic vulvovaginitis
Definition: A severe form of genital herpes caused by an initial infection with Herpes simplex and often accompanied by constitutional symptoms. In addition to the vulva, the vagina and cervix are commonly involved. The majority of cases are due to Herpes simplex virus type 2 but the condition may also be caused by type 1 virus.

Title: Herpes simplex infection of vulva
Definition: Infection of the vulva and surrounding skin by Herpes simplex virus. This is usually but not always transmitted by sexual contact and caused by Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) rather than Herpes simplex virus type 1, which is traditionally associated with orofacial herpes. It is characterised by multiple painful vesicles and superficial ulcers affecting vulval skin and mucosa. Primary genital herpes in women is more likely to involve the vagina, cervix and urethra, whereas recurrent infection tends to be more localised to the vulval area.

Title: Herpes simplex infection of penis
Definition: Infection of the penis by Herpes simplex virus. This is usually but not always transmitted by sexual contact and caused by Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) rather than Herpes simplex virus type 1, which is traditionally associated with orofacial herpes. Multiple painful vesicles and superficial ulcers develop on the glans and shaft of the penis. Primary infections tend to be more severe than recurrent attacks and are often associated with painful urethritis.

Title: Herpes simplex infection of male genital tract, not elsewhere classified
Herpes simplex infection of perianal skin or rectum
Definition: Herpes simplex infection of perianal skin and rectum. This is commonly due to Herpes simplex virus type 2 and acquired through anal sexual contact.

Title: Herpes simplex pharyngotonsillitis
Definition: This is an inflammation of the pharynx and tonsils caused by human herpes virus types HSV-1 or HSV-2.

Title: Sexually transmissible infections due to Human papillomavirus
Definition: A condition caused by an infection with Human papillomavirus (HPV). HPV is the name of a group of 200 known viruses. HPV is a common sexually transmitted infection. The condition may be characterised by precancerous lesions that can lead to cervical cancer, or the condition may be asymptomatic. HPV Infections with high-risk HPV types (also known as oncogenic types) are also associated with cancers of the vulva, vagina, mouth/throat, penis and anus. Genital warts are also a possible consequence of HPV infections. Confirmation is by identification of the Human papillomavirus (Papanicolaou test, colposcopy, Human papillomavirus DNA test or another appropriate test).

Title: Anogenital warts
Definition: Anogenital warts are due to an infection of anogenital skin and mucous membranes by certain human papilloma viruses, most commonly HPV subtypes 6, 11, 16 and 18. Transmission is predominantly by sexual contact. They manifest typically as flat plaques or papillomatous, keratinous growths on and adjacent to the external genitalia and anus. Some HPV subtypes, including types 16 and 18, are oncogenic and predispose to the development of anogenital cancers.

Title: Anal warts
Definition: Infection of the anus or perianal skin by human papillomavirus (HPV). Although the majority of such infections are sexually transmitted and caused by HPV subtypes responsible for genital warts, autoinoculation from common warts, especially on the hands in children, may also cause perianal warts.

Title: Perianal warts
Definition: Human papillomavirus infection of perianal skin.

Title: Infantile perianal warts
Definition: Perianal warts in infants are thought to arise principally as the result of infection with genital subtypes of human papillomavirus acquired during birth from the mother's birth canal.

Title: Intra-anal warts
Definition: Human papillomavirus infection of anal mucosa. This is usually the result of inoculation during penetrative sexual activity.

Title: Genital warts
Definition: Infection of anogenital mucosa or skin by the human papillomavirus. The infection is commonly asymptomatic but manifests typically as flat, papular or pedunculated growths depending on the site of infection. Transmission is normally by sexual contact.

Title: Genital warts of vulva
Definition: Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection of vulval skin. Vulval warts are usually transmitted by sexual contact. On the vulva they may appear as flat moist papules and plaques on the labia or as cauliflower-like papillomata involving the labia, perineum and perigenital skin. In some women the papillomata may become deeply pigmented resembling seborrhoeic keratoses. Infection by oncogenic strains of HPV may induce neoplastic change in the vulval epithelium (vulval intraepithelial neoplasia).

Title: Penile warts
Definition: Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection of the mucocutaneous epithelium and skin of the penis. Transmission is normally by sexual contact. Penile warts present as multiple cauliflower-like papillomata on the glans, prepuce and shaft of the penis.

Title: Genital warts of cervix
Definition: A disease of the cervix, caused by an infection with Human papillomavirus. This condition is characterised by genital warts. Transmission is commonly by sexual contact.

Title: Anogenital verrucous carcinoma of Buschke and Lowenstein
Definition: An invasive verrucous squamous cell carcinoma usually arising on the prepuce or glans penis of uncircumcised men, although it may occur elsewhere in the anogenital area. It develops from a slow but uncontrolled proliferation of human papilloma virus-infected genital epithelium and presents clinically as a papillomatous cauliflower-like tumour (giant condyloma acuminatum of Buschke and Lwenstein). It can infiltrate deeply and radical surgery may be required to eradicate it.

Title: Extragenital condylomata acuminata
Definition: Anogenital warts transmitted to extragenital sites (i.e. beyond the anogenital region). This may be through autoinoculation of anogenital wart virus to moist, intertriginous sites on the abdomen or under the breasts, or as a result of sexual activity, particularly to the lips and oral cavity.

Title: Colitis due to human papillomavirus infection
Definition: This is an inflammation of the lining of the large intestine caused by infection with human papillomavirus.

Title: Sexually transmissible viral hepatitis
Definition: Viral hepatitis which can be acquired through sexual contact, in particular hepatitis B and hepatitis D.

Title: Acute hepatitis B
Definition: Acute liver injury and inflammation caused by recent and short-term (less than 6 months) infection with hepatitis B virus (HBV). Transmission is by sexual, blood and body fluid contamination (parenteral spread), and from mother to baby at the time of birth (vertical transmission). Diagnosis is confirmed by presence of recent acquisition of HBsAg, ideally with IgM-anti-HBc in serum. Clinical features, if they occur, are characterised by anorexia, nausea and fever, with jaundice in severe cases.

Title: Acute hepatitis B with Hepatitis D virus co-infection
Definition: Acute liver injury infected simultaneously with HBV and hepatitis D virus (HDV), which is a single-stranded RNA virus. HDV requires HBV to replicate. The co-infection is diagnosed by positive serum IgM and HDV in the concomitant presence of high-titre IgM anti HBc.

Title: Acute hepatitis B without Hepatitis D virus co-infection
Definition: Acute liver injury related with hepatitis B virus (HBV). Acute hepatitis B is suspected based on positive HBsAg and high-titer IgM anti-HBc. However, other causes of acute viral hepatitis may not be fully excluded because an extensive viral examination is not available or complete clinical information is lacking.

Title: Acute hepatitis D
Definition: Acute liver injury and inflammation caused by recent and short-term (less than 6 months) infection with hepatitis D virus (HDV). Transmission only occurs in someone with chronic HBV infection (super-infection) or at the same time as acute hepatitis B (co-infection), and is by blood and body fluid contamination (parenteral spread), and sexual spread. Diagnosis is confirmed by serum IgM-anti-HDV. Clinical features, if they occur, are characterised by anorexia, nausea and fever, with jaundice in severe cases. Acute liver failure occurs in some cases, and a high proportion of cases develops chronic HDV infection.

Title: Acute hepatitis B with Hepatitis D virus co-infection
Definition: Acute liver injury infected simultaneously with HBV and hepatitis D virus (HDV), which is a single-stranded RNA virus. HDV requires HBV to replicate. The co-infection is diagnosed by positive serum IgM and HDV in the concomitant presence of high-titre IgM anti HBc.

Title: Pubic infestation by Pthirus pubis
Definition: Infestation of human pubic hair by the crab louse, Pthirus pubis.

Title: Scabies
Definition: A highly contagious infestation of the skin by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis. It may result in epidemics when introduced into institutions such as schools and nursing homes. The mites burrow into the skin, favouring the extremities, genitalia and, in infants, the axillae. The characteristic widespread intensely pruritic papulovesicular rash results largely from the host response rather than directly to burrowing by mites. Where such a response is absent as in immunosuppressed or debilitated patients, unchecked proliferation of mites results in crusted scabies. Sarcoptic mites from other mammals such as dogs may cause a transient pruritic eruption.

Title: Crusted scabies
Definition: Crusted scabies results from unchecked proliferation of the human scabies mite in individuals who are unable to mount an adequate immune response to infestation. Extensive thick crusts containing vast numbers of mites form over the skin, particularly of the extremities. Because itching is usually absent, the diagnosis is frequently overlooked. Patients with crusted scabies may serve as the source for widespread outbreaks of scabies in institutions such as hospitals and care homes.

Title: Scabietic papules or nodules
Definition: Firm itchy papules and nodules may persist for months after successful treatment of scabies, particularly on male genitalia. They may also be found in children, especially around the axillae.

Title: Animal scabies
Definition: Subspecies of Sarcoptes scabiei other than that causing human scabies (Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis) infest many different mammals and are host-specific. Close contact with infested animals (sarcoptic mange) may produce short-lived symptoms of irritation and itch in humans but the mites cannot survive and reproduce in human hosts.

Title: Vulvovaginal candidosis
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the fungi Candida. This disease is characterised by genital itching, burning, or vaginal discharge. Transmission is by endogenous spread, or sexual contact. Confirmation is commonly by identification of Candida in a vaginal swab.

Title: Symptomatic vulvovaginal candidosis
Definition: Symptomatic infection of the vulva and vagina by Candida yeasts.

Title: Asymptomatic vulvovaginal candidosis
Definition: Asymptomatic colonization of the vulva and vagina by Candida yeasts.

Title: Candida balanoposthitis
Definition: A disease caused by an infection with the fungi Candida (commonly Candida albicans). This disease is characterised by inflammation of the glans or prepuce. This disease may also present with eroded white papules, or white discharge. Transmission is by sexual contact. Confirmation is by identification of Candida in a sub-preputial swab or urine sample.

Title: Anogenital molluscum contagiosum
Definition: Molluscum contagiosum affecting the anogenital area. Transmission may be by sexual contact.

Title: Human immunodeficiency virus disease
Definition: A case of HIV infection is defined as an individual with HIV infection irrespective of clinical stage including severe or stage 4 clinical disease (also known as AIDS) confirmed by laboratory criteria according to country definitions and requirements.

Title: Human immunodeficiency virus disease associated with tuberculosis
HIV disease clinical stage 1 associated with tuberculosis
Human immunodeficiency virus disease associated with generalised lymphadenopathy
Definition: This is a lentivirus (slowly replicating retrovirus) that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), a condition in humans in which progressive failure of the immune system allows life-threatening opportunistic infections and cancers to thrive. This is a disease resulting in (persistent) generalised lymphadenopathy.

Title: Acute human immunodeficiency virus infection syndrome
Definition: This syndrome is the initial manifestation of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. One half to two thirds of patients present with an acute "mononucleosis-type" illness (fever, swollen lymph nodes, sore throat, rash, headache, malaise, arthralgia, or myalgia) often with a truncal exanthem. Symptoms generally resolve within 10-15 days. Transmission is by sexual contact, direct contact, iatrogenic transmission, or vertical transmission. Confirmation is by identification of human immunodeficiency virus in a blood sample.

Title: HIV disease clinical stage 2 associated with tuberculosis
HIV-associated immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome
Definition: Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) results from pathological immune responses occurring during immune reconstitution and is strongly associated with antiretroviral therapy for HIV infection and AIDS. There is a wide range of clinical manifestations, incorporating disease resulting from a pathological inflammatory reaction to pathogens such as tuberculosis and cryptococcosis, immune-mediated inflammatory disease and autoimmune disease. Clinical effects range from a mild, self-limiting illness to severe morbidity and mortality.

Title: Herpes resulting from human immunodeficiency virus disease
Human immunodeficiency virus disease associated with mycosis classified elsewhere
HIV disease clinical stage 3 associated with tuberculosis
Human immunodeficiency virus disease associated with haematological or immunological abnormalities
Definition: This is a lentivirus (slowly replicating retrovirus) that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), a condition in humans in which progressive failure of the immune system allows life-threatening opportunistic infections and cancers to thrive. This is a disease resulting in immunological abnormalities, not elsewhere classified.

Title: Human immunodeficiency virus disease associated with lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
Definition: This is a lentivirus (slowly replicating retrovirus) that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), a condition in humans in which progressive failure of the immune system allows life-threatening opportunistic infections and cancers to thrive. This is a disease resulting in a syndrome secondary to autoimmune and other lymphoproliferative disorders.

Title: Human immunodeficiency virus disease enteritis
Definition: This is an inflammation of small intestine associated with infection with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). In diarrhoea, a major complication of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) disease, the etiology of which is often obscure.

Title: Gastritis due to human immunodeficiency virus disease
Definition: This condition is the inflammation of the stomach due to HIV disease.

Title: Myelitis due to Human immunodeficiency virus
Definition: An inflammatory disorder of the spinal cord due to infection by the HIV virus. The symptoms and signs may be acute or subacute in onset, and include paraparesis or paraplegia, sensory loss appropriate with the level of the spinal cord affected, and loss of sphincter control. Diagnosis may be confirmed by neuroimaging, spinal fluid analysis, serological tests, and PCR assay.

Title: Human immunodeficiency virus disease associated with other types of non-Hodgkin lymphoma
Definition: This is a lentivirus (slowly replicating retrovirus) that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), a condition in humans in which progressive failure of the immune system allows life-threatening opportunistic infections and cancers to thrive. This is a disease resulting in other types of a diverse group of blood cancers that include any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas.

Title: Human immunodeficiency virus disease associated with other malignant neoplasms of lymphoid, haematopoietic or related tissue
Definition: This is a lentivirus (slowly replicating retrovirus) that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), a condition in humans in which progressive failure of the immune system allows life-threatening opportunistic infections and cancers to thrive. This is a disease resulting in other malignant neoplasms of lymphoid, haematopoietic and related tissue.

Title: Human immunodeficiency virus disease associated with multiple malignant neoplasms
Definition: This is a lentivirus (slowly replicating retrovirus) that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), a condition in humans in which progressive failure of the immune system allows life-threatening opportunistic infections and cancers to thrive. This is a disease resulting in multiple malignant neoplasms.

Title: Human immunodeficiency virus disease associated with encephalopathy
Definition: This is a lentivirus (slowly replicating retrovirus) that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), a condition in humans in which progressive failure of the immune system allows life-threatening opportunistic infections and cancers to thrive. This is a disease resulting in a disorder or disease of the brain.

Title: Dementia due to human immunodeficiency virus
Definition: Dementia due to human immunodeficiency virus develops during the course of confirmed HIV disease, in the absence of a concurrent illness or condition other than HIV infection that could explain the clinical features. Although a variety of patterns of cognitive deficit are possible depending on where the HIV pathogenic processes have occurred, typically deficits follow a subcortical pattern with impairments in executive function, processing speed, attention, and learning new information. The course of Dementia due to human immunodeficiency virus varies including resolution of symptoms, gradual decline in functioning, improvement, or fluctuation in symptoms. Rapid decline in cognitive functioning is rare with the advent of antiretroviral medications.

Title: Encephalitis due to human immunodeficiency virus Type 1
Definition: An inflammatory process of the brain, frequently with evidence of meningeal involvement, due to infection by a human immunodeficiency type 1 virus. The clinical manifestations are usually subacute, with fever and variable combinations of convulsions, impaired mental state, and focal deficits. Progressive dementia may occur. The spinal fluid may show a cellular reaction and elevated protein. Diagnosis is by neuroimaging, spinal fluid analysis and culture, PCR, and serologic tests.

Title: Encephalitis due to human immunodeficiency virus Type 2
Definition: An inflammatory process of the brain, frequently with evidence of meningeal involvement, due to infection by a human immunodeficiency type 2 virus. The clinical manifestations are usually subacute, with fever and variable combinations of convulsions, impaired mental state, and focal deficits. The spinal fluid may show a cellular reaction and elevated protein. Diagnosis is by neuroimaging, spinal fluid analysis and culture, PCR, and serologic tests.

Title: Human immunodeficiency virus disease associated with wasting syndrome
Definition: This is a lentivirus (slowly replicating retrovirus) that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), a condition in humans in which progressive failure of the immune system allows life-threatening opportunistic infections and cancers to thrive. This is a disease resulting in loss of weight, muscle atrophy, fatigue, weakness, and significant loss of appetite in someone who is not actively trying to lose weight.

Title: Oesophagitis associated with human immunodeficiency virus disease
Definition: This is an inflammation of the oesophagus associated with HIV disease. It may include several etiologies (e.g. infection, neoplasm, toxic).

Title: HIV or AIDS vacuolar myelopathy
Definition: An inflammatory and degenerative disorder of the spinal cord due to infection by the HIV virus. The posterior and lateral columns are predominantly affected and show vacuolar degeneration. The symptoms and signs are usually subacute of chronic in onset, and include spastic paraparesis or paraplegia, posterior column sensory loss, and loss of sphincter control. Diagnosis may be confirmed by neuroimaging, spinal fluid analysis, serological tests, and PCR assay.

Title: Primary HIV infection

This is a disease resulting in (persistent) generalised lymphadenopathy.

Title: Acute human immunodeficiency virus infection syndrome
Definition: This syndrome is the initial manifestation of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. One half to two thirds of patients present with an acute "mononucleosis-type" illness (fever, swollen lymph nodes, sore throat, rash, headache, malaise, arthralgia, or myalgia) often with a truncal exanthem. Symptoms generally resolve within 10-15 days. Transmission is by sexual contact, direct contact, iatrogenic transmission, or vertical transmission. Confirmation is by identification of human immunodeficiency virus in a blood sample.

Title: HIV disease clinical stage 2 without mention of tuberculosis or malaria

Definition: Symptomatic HIV infection is mainly caused by the emergence of certain opportunistic infections that the immune system would normally prevent. This stage of HIV infection is often characterised by multi-system disease and infections can occur in almost all body systems.

Title: HIV-associated immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome
Definition: Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) results from pathological immune responses occurring during immune reconstitution and is strongly associated with antiretroviral therapy for HIV infection and AIDS. There is a wide range of clinical manifestations, incorporating disease resulting from a pathological inflammatory reaction to pathogens such as tuberculosis and cryptococcosis, immune-mediated inflammatory disease and autoimmune disease. Clinical effects range from a mild, self-limiting illness to severe morbidity and mortality.

Title: Dementia due to human immunodeficiency virus
Definition: Dementia due to human immunodeficiency virus develops during the course of confirmed HIV disease, in the absence of a concurrent illness or condition other than HIV infection that could explain the clinical features. Although a variety of patterns of cognitive deficit are possible depending on where the HIV pathogenic processes have occurred, typically deficits follow a subcortical pattern with impairments in executive function, processing speed, attention, and learning new information. The course of Dementia due to human immunodeficiency virus varies including resolution of symptoms, gradual decline in functioning, improvement, or fluctuation in symptoms. Rapid decline in cognitive functioning is rare with the advent of antiretroviral medications.

Title: Encephalitis due to human immunodeficiency virus Type 1
Definition: An inflammatory process of the brain, frequently with evidence of meningeal involvement, due to infection by a human immunodeficiency type 1 virus. The clinical manifestations are usually subacute, with fever and variable combinations of convulsions, impaired mental state, and focal deficits. Progressive dementia may occur. The spinal fluid may show a cellular reaction and elevated protein. Diagnosis is by neuroimaging, spinal fluid analysis and culture, PCR, and serologic tests.

Title: Encephalitis due to human immunodeficiency virus Type 2
Definition: An inflammatory process of the brain, frequently with evidence of meningeal involvement, due to infection by a human immunodeficiency type 2 virus. The clinical manifestations are usually subacute, with fever and variable combinations of convulsions, impaired mental state, and focal deficits. The spinal fluid may show a cellular reaction and elevated protein. Diagnosis is by neuroimaging, spinal fluid analysis and culture, PCR, and serologic tests.

Title: Human immunodeficiency virus disease associated with wasting syndrome

This is a disease resulting in loss of weight, muscle atrophy, fatigue, weakness, and significant loss of appetite in someone who is not actively trying to lose weight.

Title: Oesophagitis associated with human immunodeficiency virus disease

Title: HIV or AIDS vacuolar myelopathy

The posterior and lateral columns are predominantly affected and show vacuolar degeneration. The symptoms and signs are usually subacute of chronic in onset, and include spastic paraparesis or paraplegia, posterior column sensory loss, and loss of sphincter control. Diagnosis may be confirmed by neuroimaging, spinal fluid analysis, serological tests, and PCR assay.

Title: Tuberculosis of brain

Title: Tuberculous abscess of brain

Cerebritis describes a nonencapsulated brain abscess. The signs and symptoms are variable but typically present as an expanding mass lesion, over a variable period of time, with headache, fever, and a focal neurologic deficit. Seizures may occur. Diagnosis is made by neuroimaging, histological examination, and culture of abscess material.

Title: Tuberculous infection of bile duct

Title: Tuberculosis of anal canal

Title: Tuberculous enterocolitis

Title: Cutaneous tuberculosis

Title: Tuberculous chancre
